Authors:
Karen Hughes, Matthew S. Aldrovandi, James E. Johnson,
Brian C. O’Meara, Ronald Petersen
Title:
The Xeromphalina campanella/kauffmanii complex: Species
delineation and biogeographical patterns of speciation
Keywords:
basidiomycete fungi, cryptic species, fungal
distributions, reproductive isolation, speciation patterns
Abstract:
European, North American and northeastern Asian
collections of Xeromphalina section Xeromphalina were sequenced using
the ribosomal ITS and LSU regions and RPB2. Previously designated
Xeromphalina campanella I is designated as X. campanella s. stricto, and
an epitype for this species from the topotype region is established.
This species is shown to be a discrete, cold-tolerant organism
distributed across North America and Eurasia which does not exhibit
significant geographical partitioning. A second closely related
phylogenetic species previously designated X. campanella II, is proposed
as X. enigmatica. It cannot be distinguished from X. campanella
morphologically but is reproductively isolated and is sympatric across
much of Eurasia and North America. Unlike X.campanella, it shows
geographical partitioning and some of the geographical populations have
likely achieved species status. Phylogenetic and geographical evidence
suggests that X. enigmatica may have given rise to the eastern North
American endemic, Xeromphalina kauffmanii, which is also reproductively
isolated and is characterized by a hardwood substrate and a difference
in spore shape. Two putatively interbreeding haplotypes are evident for
both eastern North American X. kauffmanii and eastern North American X.
enigmatica and may be contributions from different glacial refugia.
Cryptic taxa related to X. enigmatica are identified but not named due
to small sample sizes including Asian taxa 1-5 and an apparent endemic
from Idaho and British Columbia. Several species delineation procedures
were attempted and compared using this complex molecular data set.
Rosenbergs PAB statistic and PID (liberal) were the most liberal,
assigning species status to haplotypes or interbreeding clades within
species. PID (strict) and PRD (randomly distinct) were more stringent.
Ability to intercross was the most stringent criteria for species
delineation and did not correlate well with PAB, PID and PRD
delineations. Species delineations produced by the program Brownie
suggested 8 species in this data set but the membership in each species
was variable and apparently influenced by hybridization between
haplotypes/taxa and rare taxa with few exemplars in this data set
